content.statement: vascular:diagnostics:dx-015-waveform-analysis is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Diagnostics that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding vascular:diagnostics:dx-015-waveform-analysis helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of vascular:diagnostics:dx-015-waveform-analysis include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of vascular:diagnostics:dx-015-waveform-analysis.

definitions_glossary.concept: A fundamental idea or notion in the domain
definitions_glossary.property: A characteristic or attribute of an entity
definitions_glossary.relationship: A connection or association between concepts

triphasic.interpretation: Normal in peripheral arteries at rest
triphasic.significance: High resistance vascular bed with normal inflow

biphasic.interpretation: Mild-moderate disease OR normal variant in low-resistance beds
biphasic.significance: Reduced peripheral resistance or proximal stenosis

components: Continuous forward flow throughout cardiac cycle
monophasic.significance: Severely damped flow indicating hemodynamically significant disease

additional_findings.spectral_broadening: Turbulent flow fills in the spectral window - indicates stenosis
additional_findings.tardus_parvus: Delayed upstroke (tardus) and reduced amplitude (parvus) - distal to stenosis
additional_findings.velocity_elevation: PSV >200 cm/s at stenosis; ratio >2:1 indicates >50% stenosis

interpretation_context.common_femoral: Biphasic or monophasic suggests inflow disease (aortoiliac)
interpretation_context.SFA: Monophasic suggests SFA disease; triphasic is normal
interpretation_context.tibial: Biphasic can be normal; monophasic suggests proximal disease
interpretation_context.post_exercise: Biphasic is normal (increased demand, decreased resistance)

clinical_applications: Initial PAD screening and severity assessment

definition.@value: Classification of arterial Doppler waveforms as triphasic, biphasic, or monophasic based on flow reversal and diastolic components, providing qualitative hemodynamic assessment.

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Describe the components of triphasic, biphasic, and monophasic waveforms
Interpret waveform changes in context of anatomic location
Recognize spectral broadening and tardus-parvus patterns
Apply waveform analysis to localize arterial disease
clinical_pearls: Triphasic = normal in high-resistance beds (limbs at rest)
Loss of reversal (biphasic) is the FIRST change with proximal disease
Biphasic at common femoral suggests INFLOW disease
Biphasic at tibial level can be NORMAL
Tardus-parvus (delayed, weak) indicates disease PROXIMAL to sampling site

medicalCode.description: Duplex scan of lower extremity arteries
